38051694.review:
[h1]Played On: [b]HTC Vive[/b][/h1]

Allumette is not a game, but rather an immersive full feature short-film that lasts about twenty minutes. While you won't be able to interact with anything, if you have the room-scale space you'll be able to move around inside of the movie, and view the presentation from many different angles. This is wonderful, because the little town in the sky that Allumette takes place in is lovingly crafted, and both the environment and the characters look like they're made out of clay; which brings back nostalgic feelings for the forgotten art of stop-motion animation.

Better than the animation and virtual aesthetics, the storytelling here is brilliant. Without going in to too much detail, so as not to spoil the story, Allumette revolves around a mother and her daughter, yet the daughter finds herself cold and alone near an alley under a bridge. The story unravels from there, and it's showcased with both day and night cycles, as well as bright colors. The entire emotional tale is told without so much as even one word of dialogue or narrative, to boot.

If you've got close to half an hour to kill, and you'd rather kick back and watch a story unfold in front of you rather than play a game, then give Allumette a chance. It has been free since its release in October 2016, so it's doubtful that it will ever be put up for sale. The publisher/developer, Penrose Studios, also created The Rose and I, so if you enjoy what you see here, make sure to give that free short-film a try as well.

[h1]Rating: [b]4.0/5.0[/b] - Excellent, highly worth playing.[/h1]

35447517.review:
Before I dive into my direct experience of Allumette, I want to point out that I fully understood this was going to be a purely story based experience in VR. There are no options or strategies that make this program in any way a game. It is a very short, non verbal story experience. The beautiful characters and scenes look as if they could be rendered from brightly colored clay. The one ability the user does have in this world is to look around, focusing their attention on different parts of the scene and being able to peek inside buildings and through walls. The story itself can be experienced in 20-30 minutes, just as long as it would take one to read the short fairy tale of “The Little Match Girl” that it is based on. [spoiler] Just like the fairy tale, this story is sad enough that you will cry into your Oculus Rift. I would recommend this for older children and above based on the art and sad ending. [/spoiler]

Really, it was a beautiful looking piece of VR artwork. In order to be considered a “masterpiece” as some have claimed I would expect a bit more originality in the story board and incorporation of VR features other than visuals and basic head movement. One has to stand for the duration of the movie as well, which took me some time to feel comfortable with and I also needed to take a break a few times. The occasional black or fuzzy input would displace my vision entirely from the scene and it did not seem to be coming from my end. With how happy, cheerful and bright the art is I found it hard to ultimately feel the hopeful tragedy being conveyed and instead felt a bit rushed and frustrated that this really isn't a game and I can't influence these characters to have a better outcome. Without any words some of the implications of the ending are completely lost in the consideration of loss itself. The story's use of VR fails to give it any modern understanding or complexity. I feel quite neutral about Allumette. I don't see any reason to avoid it, but can't give you a solid reason to play it other than the threat that it won't be free forever.

This VR movie is great. It's artistically impressive, and addresses the problem of VR movies, ensuring the place where the action happens is the same place you will be looking at, There are even a few VR-specific tricks, such as being able to peek into the rooms of an airship, or the irresistable urge to catch a match-stick dropped by one of the characters over a cliff.

Alumette is a VR short animation film, in the same vein as The Rose and I, except it's loosely based on a tale by Andersen instead of The Little Prince.

This does some things right and some things wrong. 

It's a retelling of the Little Matchstick Girl, but it lacks tension and really, the stakes just aren't there leading up to the ending, to the point where if I wasn't already familiar with the story I would just be confused. The story just doesn't pack the punch it could, any punch really. The tone is soft as a cloud whereas the plot is a biting wind.

The visuals are laid out very nicely; the above/below framing was very nice. It was staged very much like a play, with minimal set changes and all the action visible at once. 

Character animation is stylistically jerky, which may be your thing. However, once in a while it isn't, which feels simply like a mistake. Non-character animation is smooth except for one moment with the ship... more or less just feels like a mistake, again. It's possible my 1070 just couldn't handle it and it has really good safeguards to make sure overall framerate never drops for comfort reasons, but I'm not so sure.

As a free experience, recommended. But it's soon to be a paid experience, and I cannot recommend one pay for it.

I cant really call this a game, because its more like having your own personal bedtime story, but its nothing short of magical and heartwarming. For such a short experience it really draws you in and really tugs at the heartstrings. Its a very different way to approach vr, and it totally works.

You're essentially watching the title characters story play out, from a sort of giants perspective, which makes the tiny characters that you see even more enchanting to watch, and because of the art style and animation the whole experience looks like it has been done using stop motion, reminiscent of childrens cartoon movies.

For me it really broadens the possibilities of vr in the future, showing how it can be used to tell stories that feel very personal to the viewer, becuause they are able to move around in the world and perhaps see things from a perspective that no one else has ever seen before.

It was disappointingly short if im honest, but mostly because i would have loved to have seen more, and i think its perhaps more of a tech demo, serving its purpose because id love to see more of this type of storytelling in the future.

great little hidden gem.

26122220.review:
This was written, directed and produced by the same guy, and it shows.

There's some really cool ideas shown for animating in VR, such as putting in little scenes that are blocked off unless you move your head through a wall to see it, giving a little extra colour and background to the characters and world. It also all looks very nice from an art style perspective. Technically speaking, it looks blurry and runs terribly, but in terms of style, it has a nice physical feel to it.

However, products like this either have to have a solid story, or excel at visuals to compensate.
This does not have a solid story. Everything is way too heavily foreshadowed, nothing's surprising and you're just waiting for it to go through the motions. It gives it a slow dragging feel to the pacing, emphasised by the credits that end like 30 seconds before the film fades to black, so you're just standing there looking at the environment you've been staring at for almost the entire film.
The characters are flat 2D placeholders. The heroic caring mother who can do no wrong and the carefree child who doesn't know how to share. There's no feeling that there's anything going on in their lives. I don't actually have any idea what they do. I think they sell sticks? Their lives are a mystery to me because they don't do anything involving their own internal motivations other than the ones prescribed by their archetypes. There's nothing there beyond the surface.

Also sometimes their actions and motivations are hindered by ... forgetfulness? i don't know, but someone on sound design or animation supervising should have made note that if a crowd can't hear someone because something's being too loud... maybe you should be able to hear what's being too loud. I know that sound was occuring earlier, but when it was really needed, it was silent.

I think i'm so harsh on this because I genuinely see a lot of cool ideas here. this could have been great, but as it is, it's something for other animators to look at and learn from. Learn from the good parts and pick out the bad.

I recommend it since it's free, but I personally wouldn't pay for this.

Premièrement, c'est gratuit et donc merci et il faut absolument s'y essayer.

Alors l'histoire...[spoiler] Vous et votre maman vendez des allumettes, un jour le bateau qui vous sert de boutique prend feu, votre maman se sacrifie et meurt pour éviter que l'explosion du bateau ne blesse quelqu'un. 26045511.review:
Allumette is a very beautiful story that last for about 25 minutes. It is a great showcase at what storytelling can do in VR. The story adds a nice spin to the classic story "The Matchstick Girl", which really highlight the use of VR while not force it to the viewers to the point where VR feels like a gimmick. The story encourages the viewer to move a little, but not to a major extend.

The story leaves me to desire more, and I will like to see more of such stories from the developer. One thing I will like to see though is to make greater use of the VR feature. There's literally nothing happening at the back, and I think it will be more lively and interesting if things didn't just happen in front, but some atmospheric non-essential stuffs can happen at the back as well (perhaps some animals roaming around, or just passengers walking).

Also it wll be great if we can manipulate the scene, such as turning the scene around literally and viewing it from another angle using the motion controllers, or even pulling the scene towards you to have a closer look so you do not need to poke your head in too much, or even pushing the scene away.

39015630.review:
Hmmm... ich bin etwas zwiegespalten. Erst mal: Es ist kein Spiel, es ist eine in 3D animierte VR Geschichte, ohne jegliche Interaktion.

Die Geschichte ist allerdings gut erzählt und kommt ohne gesprochene Worte aus, während die Spielewelt sehr gut mit dem HMD zu erkunden ist. Man kann um die Szenen herum gehen, eine eigentlich blickdichte Wand hinter sich lassen und schauen, was sich dahinter befindet, so sein eigener Kameramann sein und verschiedene Blickwinkel ausprobieren, etc.

Leider war es das auch schon: Das Erlebnis ist sehr kurz, in unter 20 Minuten ist man durch. Obwohl das "Spiel" an sich flüssig läuft, sind die Animationen der Figuren sehr hakelig, wie in einem Stop-Motion-Film, sehr schade.

Nichts desto trotz: Genau so stelle ich mir zukünftige VR-Adventures vor! Auch rundenbasierte Spiele wie X-Com könnten so eine neue Spieltiefe erfahren.

Derzeit ist es kostenlos zu haben, da kann man definitiv mal reinschauen! Je nach Preis vielleicht auch später, aber für mehr als 5€ wäre es nicht mehr empfehlenswert.

38952134.review: It is a wonderful emotional experience, a preview how watching and experiencing a movie in VR could look like in the future.
